hints_html: Recall there is only no solution if the third equation is not a linear combination of the first two. I.e. how can you make sure that the third equation is not a linear combination of the first two?
hints_latex:
Recall there is only no solution if the third equation is not a linear
combination of the first two. I.e. how can you make sure that the third
equation is not a linear combination of the first two?
hints_raw: Recall there is only no solution if the third equation is not a linear combination of the first two. I.e. how can you make sure that the third equation is not a linear combination of the first two?
question: B 06 (e)
sols_html:
We want to continue with part (d) but now find all matrices that produce no solution to 3 equations in 2 unknowns. We start with an augmented matrix in the form

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 0 & a\\ 0 & 1 & b\\ c & d & e \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

for some numbers \(a,b,c,d,e\). Notice we have put the matrix in reduced row-echelon form up to the first two rows. We did this because we know that if there were only two equations then we could find a unique solution depending the values of \(a\) and \(b\). The problem now is for those same \(a,b\) that would work in the \(2\times{2}\) case we want to find a condition on \(e\) that creates no solution. Notice we can row-reduce that last row as follows

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 0 & a\\ 0 & 1 & b\\ c & d & e \end{array}\right] \stackrel{\longrightarrow}{R3-cR1-cR2} \left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 0 & a\\ 0 & 1 & b\\ 0 & 0 & e-ca-db \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

where \(R_i\) indicates an operation on row \(i\). Notice if \(e=ca+db\) then we have a row of zeros in the matrix. This implies for a vector x with components \(x_1\) and \(x_2\) that

\[\begin{aligned} x_1&=a\\ x_2&=b\\ 0x_2&=0\end{aligned}\]

which would always hold true. Therefore, in this case there would be a solution. As discussed in part (d) this means that the third equation was secretly a linear combination of the first two equations and thus didn’t really add another constraint to the problem. Since we are seeking there to be no solution we see then that we must require,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}e\neq{}ac+bd.\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We want to continue with
{part
(d)} but now find all matrices that produce no solution to 3 equations
in 2 unknowns. We start with an augmented matrix in the form

\begin{align*}
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1  &  0  &  a\\
0  &  1  &  b\\
c  &  d  &  e
\end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

for some numbers $a,b,c,d,e$. Notice we have put the matrix in reduced
row-echelon form up to the first two rows. We did this because we know
that if there were only two equations then we could find a unique
solution depending the values of $a$ and $b$. The problem now is for
those same $a,b$ that would work in the $2\times{2}$ case we want to
find a condition on $e$ that creates no solution. Notice we can
row-reduce that last row as follows

\begin{align*}
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1  &  0  &  a\\
0  &  1  &  b\\
c  &  d  &  e
\end{array}\right]
\stackrel{\longrightarrow}{R3-cR1-cR2}
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1  &  0  &  a\\
0  &  1  &  b\\
0  &  0  &  e-ca-db
\end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

where $R_i$ indicates an operation on row $i$. Notice \textbf{if}
$e=ca+db$ then we have a row of zeros in the matrix. This implies for a
vector \textbf{x} with components $x_1$ and $x_2$ that

\begin{align*}
x_1&=a\\
x_2&=b\\
0x_2&=0
\end{align*}

which would always hold true. Therefore, in this case there would be a
solution. As discussed in
{part
(d)} this means that the third equation was secretly a linear
combination of the first two equations and thus didn't really add
another constraint to the problem. Since we are seeking there to be
\textbf{no solution} we see then that we must require,

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle{}e\neq{}ac+bd.
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
We want to continue with [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2011/Question_B6_(d)|part (d)]] but now find all matrices that produce no solution to 3 equations in 2 unknowns.  We start with an augmented matrix in the form

:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1  &  0  &  a\\
0  &  1  &  b\\
c  &  d  &  e
\end{array}\right]
</math>

for some numbers <math>a,b,c,d,e</math>.  Notice we have put the matrix in reduced row-echelon form up to the first two rows.  We did this because we know that if there were only two equations then we could find a unique solution depending the values of <math>a</math> and <math>b</math>.  The problem now is for those same <math>a,b</math> that would work in the <math>2\times{2}</math> case we want to find a condition on <math>e</math> that creates no solution.  Notice we can row-reduce that last row as follows

:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1  &  0  &  a\\
0  &  1  &  b\\
c  &  d  &  e
\end{array}\right]
\stackrel{\longrightarrow}{R3-cR1-cR2}
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1  &  0  &  a\\
0  &  1  &  b\\
0  &  0  &  e-ca-db
\end{array}\right]
</math>

where <math>R_i</math> indicates an operation on row <math>i</math>.  Notice '''if''' <math>e=ca+db</math> then we have a row of zeros in the matrix.  This implies for a vector '''x''' with components <math>x_1</math> and <math>x_2</math> that

:<math>
\begin{align}
x_1&=a\\
x_2&=b\\
0x_2&=0
\end{align}
</math>

which would always hold true.  Therefore, in this case there would be a solution.  As discussed in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2011/Question_B6_(d)|part (d)]] this means that the third equation was secretly a linear combination of the first two equations and thus didn't really add another constraint to the problem.  Since we are seeking there to be '''no solution''' we see then that we must require,

:<math>
\displaystyle{}e\neq{}ac+bd.
</math>
statement_html:
Consider the linear systems described below. In cases (a)-(d), write a single, possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix of the system.

Repeat part (d) (i.e. three equations in two unknowns with no solution) but in this case only, list all possible corresponding reduced row echelon forms.
statement_latex:
Consider the linear systems described below. In cases (a)-(d), write a
\emph{single}, possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix
of the system.

Repeat
{part
(d)} (i.e. three equations in two unknowns with no solution) but in this
case only, list \emph{all possible} corresponding reduced row echelon
forms.
statement_raw:
Consider the linear systems described below.  In cases (a)-(d), write a ''single'', possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix of the system.

Repeat [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2011/Question_B6_(d)|part (d)]] (i.e. three equations in two unknowns with no solution) but in this case only, list ''all possible'' corresponding reduced row echelon forms.
